Theatre Segregation
By JOHN BRICKAIEN

Eight Hopkins students were among the more than
400 arrested last week resulting in the successful attempt
to integrate the Northwood Theatre. The students, most
of whom were from Morgan State College, a predominantly
Negro school, were picketing the theatre to try to force the
theatre to reverse its ban on Negro patrons.
The JHU students, who were charged with disorderly
conduct and violation of the Trespass Act, are Robert Bell,
Peter Berest, Charles Capper, Steven Jarrett, Daniel Kline,
Kim Moody, Daniel Rudman and Alan Smith. All but
Smith are undergraduates.

Toward Unify Of Apperception
One apparent flaw in the sporadic rejuvenation
currently under way at Hopkins is an admissions policy
which fails to take into account some of the realities of
life at the Homewood. It is no secret that this as a more
intensely academic institution than most and that there
is correspondingly less emphasis on the "development"
of the individual by the University. As pointed out by
several often overlooked paragraphs in the catalogue,
the undergraduate is pretty much on his own here; until
recently he was entirely so.
• The oft discussed, oft misunderstood notion of the
freedom of the undergraduate at Hopkins is more than a
myth. Given a knowledge of the academic system practiced at Homewood, and an orientation toward it, the
undergraduate can get an education here second to none.
But he must do it on his own; there is no real guidance
and little direction imposed by the University. This is
a corollary to the unparalleled freedom of action allowed
the undergraduate, and a necessary consequence of it.
It has become obvious that many of the men admitted to Hopkins in recent years are incapable of taking advantage of the unique opportunities offered them.
The administration and the Committee on Undergraduate Affairs (C.O.U.G.A.) blame this, and not without
justification, on the fact that the Hopkins Community
is too amorphous. The undergraduate mind demands,
it seems, a more structured society. They have endeavored to rectify the situation to the best of their ability by
establishing Freshman dorms and deferring rushing.
Another approach to the problem might be a thorough re-examination of the admissions policy. The current set-up does not seem especially well designed to sift
out the 'Hopkins men," if there be such an animal,
from the mass of applicants. Too often it appears that
the chief concern is the pursuit, often unsuccessful, of
the well rounded, ivy type glorified by Life. We seem
to be in competition with such schools as Princeton,
Yale and Brown for "top" prospects and this is not as
it should be. The student who thrives on a relatively
spoon-fed education at these excellent universities might
well be totally lost at Hopkins.
It appears that no concerted attempt is made to
select incoming men of the maturity and specific intellectual orientation appropriate to the kind of education
Hopkins tries to provide. For example, the interviews
given here are entirely too cursory to give a real insight
into an applicant's character, and it is precisely such
intangibles as character and maturity which determine
whether Freshmen will succeed at Hopkins or become
one of Dr. Shaffer's many problems.
It is impossible to condemn the admissions policy
out of hand simply because, to the best of our knowledge, none has been made public. It is, however, entirely
possible to suggest a thorough re-evaluation to insure
that the kind of undergraduates being admitted are the
kind of undergraduates Hopkins is designed to educate.

Who'll Answer The Riddle?
The long planned "big weekend" finally is materializing and looms large on the social horizon. While the
plans are still amorphous and tentative, they present a
real innovation on the Homewood social scene. Nevertheless they reveal a multifoldinous problem which did
not seem to exist in the initial excitement which surrounded Joe Perrotto's plans last year.
At first, the concept of a "weekend" appeared as
an elixir for all the ills of the social calendar at the University. However, the glamour and anticipation of single
big social function cannot hide the deeper and graver
reality of the relative sterility of the Hopkins social man.
The university totally lacks the social traditions of
the archtypal undergraduate college. By the time the
luster of fraternity life wears off the Hopkins junior and
senior, he is left alone to fend for himself socially just
88 he has been left along to develop his academic sensibilities. However, in the academic sphere the means to
a successful education are available to the aggressive
and self realizing student; in the social realm, no such
means exist.
If the university is totally committed, as it often
tells us it is, to the development of the entire individual
it will have to provide a more realistic undergraduate
social setup. Initial steps can he provided by loosening
even further the dormitory regulations on women.
Further steps require monetary investment, but they
will nontheless be inevitable in the immanent future.
Intimate lounge or "date parlors" for small parties and
a coeducational undergraduate school have been persistent demands of News-Letter editorialists, and not
without warrant.
If the present administration ignores these pleas
in the future as they have in the past, the undergraduate will have no other recourse than the demand of a
younger and more sympathetic administrative body. That
body which too often forgets that from our side of the
fence a large investment in education has been partially
unfulfilled may someday wake HO to their failure in
developing the whole man. This ideal has been the persistent, but inconsistent goal of the public relations
propaganda which they ceaselessly spin out.

Barn Plays Emphasize
The Modern Predicament

Apres le deluge.. .Playwright Edward Albee answers questions
following the production of two of his incisive one act plays
Sunday night.

Albee Discusses
Decadent Theatre
By BOB LANDAU
Although Edward Albee's speech
at the Baltimore Museum of Art
last Sunday was entitled: "The
Theatre Today, Several Forms of
Absurdity," it actually dealt with
the playwright's function in today's theatre, his relationship
with those who produce his play,
and most important, his obligation to the audience he writes
for.
Mr. Albee feels that a medium
like the theatre, which allows
the playwright the greatest freedom of expression, far more than
in the movies or TV, should serve
as an "accurate mirror of the
nation's cultural health." But
American playwrights of today,
are lying to their audiences. They
are not questioning and debating
their values, but rather applauding them, making the theatregoing public spoiled and selfdeluded.
Absurdity Discussed
Albee then discussed the socalled "Theatre of the Absurd,"
which started soon after World
War II, by men like Beckett,
Ionesco, and Genet, playwrights
who saw a vital need for the
reexamination of men's values.
He added to this his definition
of this movement, which, he
stated, depicted "Man's attempt
to make sense for himself out
of his senseless position which
makes no sense," because he can
no longer find meaning in the
moral, political, and religious
guideposts that have been set up
for him. Each author makes use
of the stage to project his own
very personalized image of what
is wrong with man's place in
society.
Theatre Hierarchy
Returning to the Ameriran
theatre, Albee acidly described

the hierarchy of the legitimate
theatre, in wnich the most important person is the theatre
owner, whose only criteria is to
make money. Therefore
he
makes sure the play that he
books will "please everybody,
offend nobody, and run for a
long time." Next in the hierarchy
is the producer to whom the play
is not a creative effort, but
merely a "property." Next comes
the big star, famous for rewriting plays, because the author's
lines do not suit him or maintain
his image. The director also rewrites, if he feels he can help
the play "sell."
Reality Hidden
Dead last, says Albee, comes
the playwright, caught up in a
competitive, money-mad system.
The fact that he may have something to say to his audience is
very unimportant. The result is
a Broadway "top heavy" in plays
in which the ruling factors are
commercialism and big business.
Therefore we can understand
when Albee claims that in view
of these conditions, the "theatre
of the Absurd" is the true
theatre of reality, and the
theatre as we know it, with its

Inter-personal communication
and the modern predicament are
the topics of the two Albee plays
currently on the stage of the
barn theatre. "The Death of
Bessie Smith" and "The American Dream' are attempts to jar
the audience out of a lethargic
unwillingness to solve the problems of the alienated individual
in modern society.
As works of the post-existential era, Albee's plays are optimistic in that they climax in the
revealing of opportunities for
authentic relationships just as
they hopefully produce catharsis
in the playgoer and purge him
of the troubles of social living.
They readily transcend the
limitations of their specific situations so that the American
Dream becomes the Universal
Reality, the frustration of sexual desires enlarges to general
sterility and the misoriented
characters assume the greater
symbolic significance of the
general social and moral "misorder" of the contemporary
world.
The playshop's presentations
of the two plays reilect the differences in stylization of the two

GLAD RAGS
The hounds of spring are on winter's traces. Soon buds the
crocus, soon trills the giant condor, soon come the new spring
fashions to adorn our lissome limbs.
And what will the American college student wear this spring?
Gather round, you rascals, and light a Marlboro Cigarette and
enjoy that fine mellow tobacco, that pure white filter, and
possess your souls in sweet content, and listen.
As everyone knows,campus fashions have always been casual.
This spring, however, they have gone beyond being merely
casual: they have become makeshift.
The object is to look madly improvised, gaily spur-of-themoment! For example, why don't you girls try wearing a
peasant skirt with a dinner jacket? Or matador pants with a
bridal veil? Or Bermuda shorts with bronze breastplates? Be
rakish! Be impromptu! Be devil-take-the-hindmost!
And, men, you be the same. Try an opera cape with sweat
pants. Or a letter-sweater with kilts. Or a strait jacket with
hip boots. Be bold! Be daring! Be a tourist attraction!

But all is not innovation in college fashions this spring. In
fact, one of the highlights of the season turns time backward in
its flight. I refer, of course, to the comeback of the powdered
wig.
This charming accoutrement, too long neglected, has already
caught on with in undergrads everywhere. On hundreds of
campuses the bossa nova is giving way to the minuet, and
patriotic undergraduates are dumping British tea into the
nearest harbor. This, as you may imagine, does not sit well with
King George III who, according to reliable reports, has been
stamping his foot and uttering curses not fit to reproduce in
this family newspaper. For that matter, a lot of our own people
are steamed up too,and there has even been some talk about the
American colonies declaring their independence of England.
But I hardly think it will come to that. I mean, how can we
break with the mother country when we are dependent on her
for so many things—linsey-woolsey, Minie balls, taper snuffers,
and like that? She, on the other hand, relies on us for turkeys,
Marlboro Cigarettes, and Route 66. So I say, if Molly Pitcher
and those other Radcliffe hotheads will calm down, and if
gentlemen will cry "Peace! Peace!" we may yet find an
amicable solution to our differences. But let not our British
cousins mistake this willingness to negotiate for weakness. If
fight we must, then fight we will! Paul Revere is saddled up,
the rude bridge arches the flood, and the ROTC is armed!

The freshman fencing squad
closed its season on Wednesday,
February 20, with a 22-5 loss
to the Navy plebes. Joel Goldstein was the only winner of
the nine foil bouts for Hopkins,
as was Walt Di.scenza in sabre.
In epee, Jeff Zabler was a triple
winner to account for the remaining Hopkin's victorys. Bill
Brumfield and Walt Rosett were
both 0-2 in epee, but each had
a 5-4 loss.
Said Coach Oles of the match,
"Our epee team was easily equal
to Navy's and with a little more
experience, might have taken
six out of nine. The team as a
whole did well in view of the
fact that the plebes had been

practicing three months longer
than we."
Bill Brumfield took the Amateur Fencers League of America
Novic Epee crown with a 6-0
record last Sunday, and Walt
Rosett placed second on touches.
"More Talented"
Coach Oles summed up the
froth season thus: "We had a
much more athletic and talented
group than in previous years. Although our record was only 2-5
for the season, this is no real
measure of our ability, since
three of the teams that beat us
had had at least a year's more
experience. We beat the teams
on our own level.
"The freshman year is 'hell
year' for Hopkins fencers be-

cause they are thrown up against
more experienced teams. We do
this deliberately — if a boy wins
against more experienced opponents, we know we've got
talent.'
Coach Rates Team
Coach Oles rated Zablerp,
Nusbaum, Rosett and Brumfield,
all four members of the frosh
epee team, as definite varsity
material. He feels that Walt
Discenza and Bill Kleinwachter
of sabre will successfully make
the transition to the varsity
squad, as will Hank Spalinger,
Lou Russo, Vince Curti, Larry
Pinkus, and Joel Goldstein in
foil.

A GOOD TEAM
By BARD
At the beginning of the curgent wrestling season, a grim
pessimism pervaded the Hopkins
campus. The wrestling team, if
there was going to be one, was
not going to win any meets.
Bt was going to have to forfeit a
number of bouts due to insufficient manpower; it wasn't even
going to come close to winning
any meets. Voluntary Red Cross
workers were recruited to carry
the soon-to-be-decimated
off
Hopkins wrestlers,
Well, the official season is over,
and Hopkins wound up 4-5. This
is not a world shatterring mark,
but it is an improvement over
the 2-7 mark posted last year,
and a definite improvement over
the expected 0-9.
Give Us More
In retrospect, the question is
not so much How Hopkins managed to win 4, but rather how
they managed to avoid winning
6. This is not at all intended to
be critical. The squad was made
up almost entirely of sophomores, and the lack of experience of these sophomores
made Winning 6 an impossibility, since, being inexperienced, they were bound to make
mistakes. An error, coming from
inexperience, gave Loyola a 1716 win in a match which should
have been a 19-12 Hopkins victory. Coach Mickey Cochrane
went on the record as saying
that if the team had performed
as well against Dickinson as it
did against Delaware, it would
have won that match. The reasons that the squad did not do
so were minor injuries, tough
breaks, and inexperience.
Fans, Fighters
Hopkins, however, possesses a
number of fine wrestlers and
one extraordinary wrestling fan.
The former have kept winning,
and the overall point total for
the year is in Hopkins favor, and
the latter is so enthusiastic that
he was drafted onto the squad
last year, when injuries had depleted the grappling ranks.
A lot of credit has to go out to
captain Ron Davis. The only
senior, and the only returning
letterman, Davis has had multiple responsibilities this year,
and has done well. He has a
winning record, and has also
managed to act as a stabilizing
influence on the sophomores,
perhaps his most important
function as captain.

Sophomores shine
The real wrestling story, however, lies in the sophomores, and
Hopkins has a slew of fine
Mike
wrestlers.
sophomore
Schneider, Frank Szoka, John
Glascock, Joe Viglotti, Mel Ulmer, and Jim Fisher have all
turned in outstanding perform a nces.

Fisher Successful
Fisher is a high-school wrestling champion, and his work on

Toward Unify Of Apperception
One apparent flaw in the sporadic rejuvenation
currently under way at Hopkins is an admissions policy
which fails to take into account some of the realities of
life at the Homewood. It is no secret that this as a more
intensely academic institution than most and that there
is correspondingly less emphasis on the "development"
of the individual by the University. As pointed out by
several often overlooked paragraphs in the catalogue,
the undergraduate is pretty much on his own here; until
recently he was entirely so.
• The oft discussed, oft misunderstood notion of the
freedom of the undergraduate at Hopkins is more than a
myth. Given a knowledge of the academic system practiced at Homewood, and an orientation toward it, the
undergraduate can get an education here second to none.
But he must do it on his own; there is no real guidance
and little direction imposed by the University. This is
a corollary to the unparalleled freedom of action allowed
the undergraduate, and a necessary consequence of it.
It has become obvious that many of the men admitted to Hopkins in recent years are incapable of taking advantage of the unique opportunities offered them.
The administration and the Committee on Undergraduate Affairs (C.O.U.G.A.) blame this, and not without
justification, on the fact that the Hopkins Community
is too amorphous. The undergraduate mind demands,
it seems, a more structured society. They have endeavored to rectify the situation to the best of their ability by
establishing Freshman dorms and deferring rushing.
Another approach to the problem might be a thorough re-examination of the admissions policy. The current set-up does not seem especially well designed to sift
out the 'Hopkins men," if there be such an animal,
from the mass of applicants. Too often it appears that
the chief concern is the pursuit, often unsuccessful, of
the well rounded, ivy type glorified by Life. We seem
to be in competition with such schools as Princeton,
Yale and Brown for "top" prospects and this is not as
it should be. The student who thrives on a relatively
spoon-fed education at these excellent universities might
well be totally lost at Hopkins.
It appears that no concerted attempt is made to
select incoming men of the maturity and specific intellectual orientation appropriate to the kind of education
Hopkins tries to provide. For example, the interviews
given here are entirely too cursory to give a real insight
into an applicant's character, and it is precisely such
intangibles as character and maturity which determine
whether Freshmen will succeed at Hopkins or become
one of Dr. Shaffer's many problems.
It is impossible to condemn the admissions policy
out of hand simply because, to the best of our knowledge, none has been made public. It is, however, entirely
possible to suggest a thorough re-evaluation to insure
that the kind of undergraduates being admitted are the
kind of undergraduates Hopkins is designed to educate.

Who'll Answer The Riddle?
The long planned "big weekend" finally is materializing and looms large on the social horizon. While the
plans are still amorphous and tentative, they present a
real innovation on the Homewood social scene. Nevertheless they reveal a multifoldinous problem which did
not seem to exist in the initial excitement which surrounded Joe Perrotto's plans last year.
At first, the concept of a "weekend" appeared as
an elixir for all the ills of the social calendar at the University. However, the glamour and anticipation of single
big social function cannot hide the deeper and graver
reality of the relative sterility of the Hopkins social man.
The university totally lacks the social traditions of
the archtypal undergraduate college. By the time the
luster of fraternity life wears off the Hopkins junior and
senior, he is left alone to fend for himself socially just
88 he has been left along to develop his academic sensibilities. However, in the academic sphere the means to
a successful education are available to the aggressive
and self realizing student; in the social realm, no such
means exist.
If the university is totally committed, as it often
tells us it is, to the development of the entire individual
it will have to provide a more realistic undergraduate
social setup. Initial steps can he provided by loosening
even further the dormitory regulations on women.
Further steps require monetary investment, but they
will nontheless be inevitable in the immanent future.
Intimate lounge or "date parlors" for small parties and
a coeducational undergraduate school have been persistent demands of News-Letter editorialists, and not
without warrant.
If the present administration ignores these pleas
in the future as they have in the past, the undergraduate will have no other recourse than the demand of a
younger and more sympathetic administrative body. That
body which too often forgets that from our side of the
fence a large investment in education has been partially
unfulfilled may someday wake HO to their failure in
developing the whole man. This ideal has been the persistent, but inconsistent goal of the public relations
propaganda which they ceaselessly spin out.

Albee Discusses
Decadent Theatre
By BOB LANDAU
Although Edward Albee's speech
at the Baltimore Museum of Art
last Sunday was entitled: "The
Theatre Today, Several Forms of
Absurdity," it actually dealt with
the playwright's function in today's theatre, his relationship
with those who produce his play,
and most important, his obligation to the audience he writes
for.
Mr. Albee feels that a medium
like the theatre, which allows
the playwright the greatest freedom of expression, far more than
in the movies or TV, should serve
as an "accurate mirror of the
nation's cultural health." But
American playwrights of today,
are lying to their audiences. They
are not questioning and debating
their values, but rather applauding them, making the theatregoing public spoiled and selfdeluded.
Absurdity Discussed
Albee then discussed the socalled "Theatre of the Absurd,"
which started soon after World
War II, by men like Beckett,
Ionesco, and Genet, playwrights
who saw a vital need for the
reexamination of men's values.
He added to this his definition
of this movement, which, he
stated, depicted "Man's attempt
to make sense for himself out
of his senseless position which
makes no sense," because he can
no longer find meaning in the
moral, political, and religious
guideposts that have been set up
for him. Each author makes use
of the stage to project his own
very personalized image of what
is wrong with man's place in
society.
Theatre Hierarchy
Returning to the Ameriran
theatre, Albee acidly described

the hierarchy of the legitimate
theatre, in wnich the most important person is the theatre
owner, whose only criteria is to
make money. Therefore
he
makes sure the play that he
books will "please everybody,
offend nobody, and run for a
long time." Next in the hierarchy
is the producer to whom the play
is not a creative effort, but
merely a "property." Next comes
the big star, famous for rewriting plays, because the author's
lines do not suit him or maintain
his image. The director also rewrites, if he feels he can help
the play "sell."
Reality Hidden
Dead last, says Albee, comes
the playwright, caught up in a
competitive, money-mad system.
The fact that he may have something to say to his audience is
very unimportant. The result is
a Broadway "top heavy" in plays
in which the ruling factors are
commercialism and big business.
Therefore we can understand
when Albee claims that in view
of these conditions, the "theatre
of the Absurd" is the true
theatre of reality, and the
theatre as we know it, with its

Inter-personal communication
and the modern predicament are
the topics of the two Albee plays
currently on the stage of the
barn theatre. "The Death of
Bessie Smith" and "The American Dream' are attempts to jar
the audience out of a lethargic
unwillingness to solve the problems of the alienated individual
in modern society.
As works of the post-existential era, Albee's plays are optimistic in that they climax in the

GLAD RAGS
The hounds of spring are on winter's traces. Soon buds the
crocus, soon trills the giant condor, soon come the new spring
fashions to adorn our lissome limbs.
And what will the American college student wear this spring?
Gather round, you rascals, and light a Marlboro Cigarette and
enjoy that fine mellow tobacco, that pure white filter, and
possess your souls in sweet content, and listen.
As everyone knows,campus fashions have always been casual.
This spring, however, they have gone beyond being merely
casual: they have become makeshift.
The object is to look madly improvised, gaily spur-of-themoment! For example, why don't you girls try wearing a
peasant skirt with a dinner jacket? Or matador pants with a
bridal veil? Or Bermuda shorts with bronze breastplates? Be
rakish! Be impromptu! Be devil-take-the-hindmost!
And, men, you be the same. Try an opera cape with sweat
pants. Or a letter-sweater with kilts. Or a strait jacket with
hip boots. Be bold! Be daring! Be a tourist attraction!

But all is not innovation in college fashions this spring. In
fact, one of the highlights of the season turns time backward in
its flight. I refer, of course, to the comeback of the powdered
wig.
This charming accoutrement, too long neglected, has already
caught on with in undergrads everywhere. On hundreds of
campuses the bossa nova is giving way to the minuet, and
patriotic undergraduates are dumping British tea into the
nearest harbor. This, as you may imagine, does not sit well with
King George III who, according to reliable reports, has been
stamping his foot and uttering curses not fit to reproduce in
this family newspaper. For that matter, a lot of our own people
are steamed up too,and there has even been some talk about the
American colonies declaring their independence of England.
But I hardly think it will come to that. I mean, how can we
break with the mother country when we are dependent on her
for so many things—linsey-woolsey, Minie balls, taper snuffers,
and like that? She, on the other hand, relies on us for turkeys,
Marlboro Cigarettes, and Route 66. So I say, if Molly Pitcher
and those other Radcliffe hotheads will calm down, and if
gentlemen will cry "Peace! Peace!" we may yet find an
amicable solution to our differences. But let not our British
cousins mistake this willingness to negotiate for weakness. If
fight we must, then fight we will! Paul Revere is saddled up,
the rude bridge arches the flood, and the ROTC is armed!

The freshman fencing squad
closed its season on Wednesday,
February 20, with a 22-5 loss
to the Navy plebes. Joel Goldstein was the only winner of
the nine foil bouts for Hopkins,
as was Walt Di.scenza in sabre.
In epee, Jeff Zabler was a triple
winner to account for the remaining Hopkin's victorys. Bill
Brumfield and Walt Rosett were
both 0-2 in epee, but each had
a 5-4 loss.
Said Coach Oles of the match,
"Our epee team was easily equal
to Navy's and with a little more
experience, might have taken
six out of nine. The team as a
whole did well in view of the
fact that the plebes had been

practicing three months longer
than we."
Bill Brumfield took the Amateur Fencers League of America
Novic Epee crown with a 6-0
record last Sunday, and Walt
Rosett placed second on touches.
"More Talented"
Coach Oles summed up the
froth season thus: "We had a
much more athletic and talented
group than in previous years. Although our record was only 2-5
for the season, this is no real
measure of our ability, since
three of the teams that beat us
had had at least a year's more
experience. We beat the teams
on our own level.
"The freshman year is 'hell
year' for Hopkins fencers be-

cause they are thrown up against
more experienced teams. We do
this deliberately — if a boy wins
against more experienced opponents, we know we've got
talent.'
Coach Rates Team
Coach Oles rated Zablerp,
Nusbaum, Rosett and Brumfield,
all four members of the frosh
epee team, as definite varsity
material. He feels that Walt
Discenza and Bill Kleinwachter
of sabre will successfully make
the transition to the varsity
squad, as will Hank Spalinger,
Lou Russo, Vince Curti, Larry
Pinkus, and Joel Goldstein in
foil.

A GOOD TEAM
By BARD
At the beginning of the curgent wrestling season, a grim
pessimism pervaded the Hopkins
campus. The wrestling team, if
there was going to be one, was
not going to win any meets.
Bt was going to have to forfeit a
number of bouts due to insufficient manpower; it wasn't even
going to come close to winning
any meets. Voluntary Red Cross
workers were recruited to carry
the soon-to-be-decimated
off
Hopkins wrestlers,
Well, the official season is over,
and Hopkins wound up 4-5. This
is not a world shatterring mark,
but it is an improvement over
the 2-7 mark posted last year,
and a definite improvement over
the expected 0-9.
Give Us More
In retrospect, the question is
not so much How Hopkins managed to win 4, but rather how
they managed to avoid winning
6. This is not at all intended to
be critical. The squad was made
up almost entirely of sophomores, and the lack of experience of these sophomores
made Winning 6 an impossibility, since, being inexperienced, they were bound to make
mistakes. An error, coming from
inexperience, gave Loyola a 1716 win in a match which should
have been a 19-12 Hopkins victory. Coach Mickey Cochrane
went on the record as saying
that if the team had performed
as well against Dickinson as it
did against Delaware, it would
have won that match. The reasons that the squad did not do
so were minor injuries, tough
breaks, and inexperience.
Fans, Fighters
Hopkins, however, possesses a
number of fine wrestlers and
one extraordinary wrestling fan.
The former have kept winning,
and the overall point total for
the year is in Hopkins favor, and
the latter is so enthusiastic that
he was drafted onto the squad
last year, when injuries had depleted the grappling ranks.
A lot of credit has to go out to
captain Ron Davis. The only
senior, and the only returning
letterman, Davis has had multiple responsibilities this year,
and has done well. He has a
winning record, and has also
managed to act as a stabilizing
influence on the sophomores,
perhaps his most important
function as captain.

Sophomores shine
The real wrestling story, however, lies in the sophomores, and
Hopkins has a slew of fine
Mike
wrestlers.
sophomore
Schneider, Frank Szoka, John
Glascock, Joe Viglotti, Mel Ulmer, and Jim Fisher have all
turned in outstanding perform a nces.
